text: Yeah. So let me just first make the point that there's two VIX ETFs, ETPs, that have both effectively gone bankrupt. They do the exact opposite thing. So the VXX, by all counts, I think launched in 2011. It's split so many times, it's effectively gone bankrupt. And then the XIV, we know, was dealt a very rapid death in Feb of 18. So these two things, if they traded with each other, would effectively earn the risk-free rate, which wasn't much for a long time, but they've both gone under. So I asked myself, is it better to be long or short vol? And it's just a question to really, it's really difficult to answer. I think most of the back tests will tell you there's a VRP, a vol risk premium. But I really do believe in the value of trying to find cheap optionality. And I think it's no easy task. I don't think it's a very easy task. I don't think it's a very easy task. I don't think you can systematically find it. But I do think that there's alpha to be had in trying to figure out if there are clever trades to be done, whether there's optionality that's just gotten too cheap for some reason. There are times when, again, hindsight can be 20-20, but I do think really pushing back and trying to get clients to consider when there's opportunities to expend option premium. Give you a quick example. Again, hindsight's 20-20, but the price of one-year options, 5% of the money puts on Apple was the cheapest of all time in the week before the earnings. The stock's down a fair amount since the earnings, vol is up. So with the stock at an all-time high and the puts prices at an all-time low, and these aren't one-day options, these are one-year options, and not a lot of people bought those options. So it's a hard question to answer in terms, whether vol is cheap or rich. I would say that sometimes it's both the most cheap and most rich at the same time. Let me explain. In October of 2017, on the 35th anniversary of the 87 crash, I did a dinner. And going into that dinner, the price of a one-month straddle on the S&P was 1.5% of spot. So over a one-month period, if the S&P went up or down a percent and a half, over the course of an entire month, you're going to make money. No one was buying that straddle. They were selling that straddle because they realized vol going into it was something like four or five. So when markets flatline like they did late 17, vol is going to get super, super cheap. It becomes so difficult to carry. It's like anything. You focus a lot on the value factor, the kind of time variation of factors. And we know that that value factor got its cheapest relative to the expensive stuff at a time when people were finding new reasons not to embrace value. It's a new paradigm. Everybody's got to own a Peloton, Zoom. It's tough stuff. So when you talk about richness or cheapness, you could talk about carry. I tend to really try to think about when you can find that rare combination of when options are carrying at a pretty interesting level, but also the implied vol is low in historical context. It's hard to find that. It doesn't happen that often, or even when it does happen, it doesn't stay that way for that often. But that's how I would think about the combo of trying to find favorable realized to implied spreads, but also low implied at the same time.
